hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
o4-mini_translation: Nāmakaokapāoʻo was a very small child, yet he was exceedingly strong in his youth. There was no one like him on these islands from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau in both his small stature and his bravery. His father was Kauluakahaʻi, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinuʻu. His mother was Pōkaʻī. His father was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was also part god.
o4-mini_commentary:
• Narrative structure and cultural context  
  – This opening paragraph follows the classic moʻolelo formula by presenting:  
    1) The protagonist’s name and physical attributes (a);  
    2) The names and statuses of his parents (b1, b2);  
    3) The geographical and cosmological origins of the family (c).  
  – Such introductions are characteristic of pre-contact Hawaiian heroic chants, where genealogy and supernatural connection establish a character’s mana and legitimacy.

• The hero: Nāmakaokapāoʻo (a)  
  – Etymology: nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo “the eyes of the pāoʻo.” The pāoʻo is a brightly colored fish; invoking its “eyes” suggests keen sight, vigilance, or an uncanny perception.  
  – Physique and prowess:  
    • “He keiki ʻuʻuku loa” (a very small child) yet “he keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ʻōpiopio” (exceedingly strong as a youth)  
    • “ʻAʻohe ona lua ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawaiʻi ā Niʻihau” (unmatched from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau) – a pan-island superlative underscoring his unique combination of diminutive size and extraordinary courage  
  – Allegorical resonance: the paradox of small stature with vast strength prefigures the underdog-hero motif, common in Hawaiian tradition, where outward humility cloaks inner, often divine, power.

• The father: Kauluakahaʻi (b1, c)  
  – Name and genealogy: Kaulu-a-Kahaʻi “the inspiration (kaulu) of Kahaʻi,” linking him to the legendary hero Kahaʻi, who voyages to Kahiki (foreign lands) in other narratives.  
  – Origin:  
    • “No Kahikipapaialewa” – a stratum of Kahiki situated aloft, representing a celestial foreign land; Kahikipapaialewa often appears in chants to locate chiefs within a cosmic geography.  
    • Kahikinuʻu “Kahiki at the summit,” reinforcing the notion of Kahiki as both a physical and mythic realm.  
  – Status and divinity:  
    • “He aliʻi nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa” – he is a high chief of that realm, affirming noble rank.  
    • “He ʻaoʻao akua kekahi ona” – he is part-god (a demigod), a common attribute in chiefly genealogies of the ʻAi Kapu era, which authorized and protected chiefly authority under the kapu system.

• The mother: Pōkaʻī (b2)  
  – Name etymology: possibly Pō (“darkness” or the primal night) + kaʻi (“to lead,” “to steer,” “to encompass”), suggesting a role as hinge or guide between realms.  
  – Narrative role: though no further description is given, inclusion of the mother’s name emphasizes bilateral genealogy and acknowledges her part in the hero’s lineage, a practice that foregrounds both paternal and maternal descent in Hawaiian thought.

• Broader cultural implications  
  – Genealogical presentations such as this anchored chiefly lines in both earthly and cosmic orders, linking human leaders to the gods and to foreign (Kahiki) origins.  
  – The juxtaposition of “ʻuʻuku” and “koa” (smallness and valor) in one individual reflects Hawaiian values that esteem inner strength and resourcefulness over mere physical dominance.  
  – By tracing descent to Kahikipapaialewa, the text situates Nāmakaokapāoʻo within an otherworldly narrative realm, setting the stage for exploits that transcend ordinary island life and engage with the supernatural.
raw_response:
<translation>  
Nāmakaokapāoʻo was a very small child, yet he was exceedingly strong in his youth. There was no one like him on these islands from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau in both his small stature and his bravery. His father was Kauluakahaʻi, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinuʻu. His mother was Pōkaʻī. His father was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was also part god.  
</translation>

<commentary>  
• Narrative structure and cultural context  
  – This opening paragraph follows the classic moʻolelo formula by presenting:  
    1) The protagonist’s name and physical attributes (a);  
    2) The names and statuses of his parents (b1, b2);  
    3) The geographical and cosmological origins of the family (c).  
  – Such introductions are characteristic of pre-contact Hawaiian heroic chants, where genealogy and supernatural connection establish a character’s mana and legitimacy.

• The hero: Nāmakaokapāoʻo (a)  
  – Etymology: nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo “the eyes of the pāoʻo.” The pāoʻo is a brightly colored fish; invoking its “eyes” suggests keen sight, vigilance, or an uncanny perception.  
  – Physique and prowess:  
    • “He keiki ʻuʻuku loa” (a very small child) yet “he keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ʻōpiopio” (exceedingly strong as a youth)  
    • “ʻAʻohe ona lua ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawaiʻi ā Niʻihau” (unmatched from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau) – a pan-island superlative underscoring his unique combination of diminutive size and extraordinary courage  
  – Allegorical resonance: the paradox of small stature with vast strength prefigures the underdog-hero motif, common in Hawaiian tradition, where outward humility cloaks inner, often divine, power.

• The father: Kauluakahaʻi (b1, c)  
  – Name and genealogy: Kaulu-a-Kahaʻi “the inspiration (kaulu) of Kahaʻi,” linking him to the legendary hero Kahaʻi, who voyages to Kahiki (foreign lands) in other narratives.  
  – Origin:  
    • “No Kahikipapaialewa” – a stratum of Kahiki situated aloft, representing a celestial foreign land; Kahikipapaialewa often appears in chants to locate chiefs within a cosmic geography.  
    • Kahikinuʻu “Kahiki at the summit,” reinforcing the notion of Kahiki as both a physical and mythic realm.  
  – Status and divinity:  
    • “He aliʻi nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa” – he is a high chief of that realm, affirming noble rank.  
    • “He ʻaoʻao akua kekahi ona” – he is part-god (a demigod), a common attribute in chiefly genealogies of the ʻAi Kapu era, which authorized and protected chiefly authority under the kapu system.

• The mother: Pōkaʻī (b2)  
  – Name etymology: possibly Pō (“darkness” or the primal night) + kaʻi (“to lead,” “to steer,” “to encompass”), suggesting a role as hinge or guide between realms.  
  – Narrative role: though no further description is given, inclusion of the mother’s name emphasizes bilateral genealogy and acknowledges her part in the hero’s lineage, a practice that foregrounds both paternal and maternal descent in Hawaiian thought.

• Broader cultural implications  
  – Genealogical presentations such as this anchored chiefly lines in both earthly and cosmic orders, linking human leaders to the gods and to foreign (Kahiki) origins.  
  – The juxtaposition of “ʻuʻuku” and “koa” (smallness and valor) in one individual reflects Hawaiian values that esteem inner strength and resourcefulness over mere physical dominance.  
  – By tracing descent to Kahikipapaialewa, the text situates Nāmakaokapāoʻo within an otherworldly narrative realm, setting the stage for exploits that transcend ordinary island life and engage with the supernatural.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
